metadata.title: Recommender System — Advanced Matrix Factorization | by Denise Chen | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Walk Through Recommender System of Advanced Matrix Factorization for the implicit dataset

all_paragraphs: The implicit dataset provides users’ behavior data such as purchase history, watching habits, and browsing activity. Unlike explicit feedback from users rating data, the implicit dataset is lack of direct indication of their preferences. Therefore, it’s hard to know which products customers dislike. The model we work below generates unique properties of implicit feedback datasets. The confidence level is varied from positive and negative preferences.
In this article, you will learn the algorithm of advanced matrix factorization of the recommender system:
(2) Introduction to Latent factor models
(3) Introduction to Model for Implicit Feedback
(4) Hands-on experience of python code on matrix factorization

The neighborhood model is a common approach among the Collaborative Filtering algorithm. Such an approach is to recommend users with the same interest based on the history dataset. Better scalability and improved accuracy make the item-oriented approach more favorable in many cases. In those methods, a rating is estimated using known ratings made by the same user on similar items. Better scalability and improved accuracy make the item-oriented approach more favorable in many cases. The item-oriented approach is more favorable to users since they are familiar with items previously preferred by them, and the recommended items are based on same-interest users.

A similarity measure is applied for the neighborhood model where s_ij denotes the similarity of i and j, and is calculated by the Pearson correlation coefficient. The goal is to predict r_ui — the unobserved value by user u for item i. S^k(i;u) is denoted by a set of k neighbors and the predicted value of r_ui is taken as a weighted average of the ratings for neighboring items.

The latent factor model is an alternative Collaborative Filtering approach to uncover latent features that explain observed ratings. Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) is the main algorithm introduced for the latent factor model. The SVD model becomes a popular user-item observation method.
An SVD model is comprised of a user-factors vector X_u and item-factors vector Y_i. The prediction is generated by the inner product r^ui = X^T_u*Y_i. λ is the parameter for regularization.

2. Confidence variable: C_ui is a confidence measure by the observation of P_ui. For every user-item pair, it is set with some minimal confidence in P_ui. The confidence measure increases along with positive preference through constant α.
The term λ is used to regularize the model to prevent overfitting on the training data. There are m and n terms in the cost function, where m is the number of users and n is the number of items.

Alternating least squares is used to lower the value of the cost function while computing user-factors and item-factors. Such a method is used for an explicit dataset and treats all unknown values as missing values, leading to a sparse objective function. An alternative way to extract P_ui is to set the minimum threshold from R_ui for the corresponding non-zero value of P_ui. Likewise, confidence level C_ui can be transformed from R_ui.
There are two main properties to be addressed to the unique characteristics of implicit feedback.

This dataset contains social networking, tagging, and music artist listening information from a set of 2K users from Last.fm online music system. There are a total of 1892 and 17632 artists. There is a 12717 bi-directional user friend relations with 25434 (user_i, user_j) pairs. From users’ history data of listened to artists, there are 92834 user-listened artist relations and an average of 5.265 users who listened to each artist.

The data is separated by the tab of each column and has ‘userID’, ‘artistID’, and ‘weight’ columns. We get a total of 278502 number of artists listened by the artists. After we drop the duplicated records (if someone listens to the same songs twice), there are 1892 users and 17632 artists in the data.

A function used to mask the preferences data from the training matrix. The training matrix is created by the artist listened by the users and mask it to the training matrix. The test matrix is created based on the users’ history dataset.

Before the model creation, the preference matrix is generated from a placeholder function which is used to build the computation graph without the need for the data. Also, the predicted preferences matrix is done by taking an inner product rˆui = x^T_u*y_i. Later on, we take the squared error of actual and predicted preference matrix, multiply by the confidence matrix and sum the product value of lambda with the loss function. This is where we minimize the cost function from the above method. The cost function is stated below. Top_k_precision is a function that helps to calculate the top k item average predicted precisions by the intersection of the recommended artists and the artists favored by the users.

Recommendation System model1. Get the predicted matrix for recommendations 2. Target the top-recommended artist from the user's history dataset3. Map the artists from users’ history data and recommended artist 4. Get the result of the intersection from the above mapping methods for top K artists
